leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.2] r 14.2 Trial without further pleadings (cf SCR Part 15, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Trial without further pleadings (cf SCR Part 15, rule 2)

p.text: If in the opinion of the court:
the issues between the parties can be defined without further pleadings, or
for any other reason the proceedings may properly be tried without further pleadings,
the court may order that the proceedings be so tried.

A court that makes an order under subrule (1) may direct the parties to prepare a statement of the issues involved in the proceedings or, if the parties do not agree on a statement, may settle a statement itself.
The approved form is Form 12 : Statement of issues.
Legislation cited in [14.2.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56.

A properly pleaded statement of claim performs the function of briefly and explicitly stating the material factual allegations which support the claim. By so doing, the statement of claim gives the defendant proper notice and the consequential opportunity to answer the claim. A properly pleaded defence traverses only matters that are genuinely in dispute, and thereby identifies the matters requiring determination in the proceedings. The function of providing proper notice is fundamental to the basic requirement of procedural fairness: Banque Commerciale SA (in liq) v Akhil Holdings Ltd (1990) 169 CLR 279 at 286; 92 ALR 53; BC9002932 per Mason CJ and Gaudron J; Multigroup Distribution Services Pty Ltd v TNT Australia Pty Ltd (1996) ATPR ¶41-522 at 42,678 per Burchett J. By performing that basic function, pleadings also identify the issues in dispute and promote the efficient conduct of proceedings. They confine, or at least identify, the genuinely contested issues and facilitate assessment of the relevance and admissibility of evidence: Dare v Pulham (1982) 148 CLR 658 at 664; 44 ALR 117; BC8200139 ; Banque Commerciale SA (in liq) v Akhil Holdings Ltd (1990) 169 CLR 279 at 296; 92 ALR 53; BC9002932 ; Goldsmith v Sandilands (2002) 190 ALR 370; 76 ALJR 1024; [2002] HCA 31; BC200204358 at [2] . Pleadings also provide the factual criteria for various interlocutory procedures, such as discovery, interrogatories and orders to provide particulars. Ultimately they record the matters the court necessarily decided in the proceedings and determine the scope of any issue estoppel or res judicata estoppel: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission v Fox Symes & Associates Pty Ltd [2005] FCA 1071; BC200505572 at [100]–[103] . It follows that no pedantry is involved in emphasising the importance of formal and proper pleading: Mitanis v Pioneer Concrete (Vic) Pty Ltd (1997) ATPR ¶41-591 at 44,151; BC9705104 citing Esso Petroleum Co Ltd v Southport Corp [1956] AC 218 at 241; [1955] 3 All ER 864 ; Banque Commerciale SA (in liq) v Akhil Holdings Ltd (1990) 169 CLR 279 at 286; 92 ALR 53; BC9002932 . And although the court will be influenced by matters of substance, and not matters of mere technicality (Bright v Sampson & Duncan Enterprises Pty Ltd (1985) 1 NSWLR 346 at 353), it is both “bad law and bad practice” to dismiss criticism of pleadings as a “mere pleading point”: Farrell (formerly McLaughlin) v Secretary for Defence [1980] 1 WLR 172 at 180. Proper pleading is of fundamental importance in assisting courts to achieve the overriding purpose of just, quick and cheap resolution of proceedings: see CPA s 56 .

level.toc-caption: [14.2.15] Consequences of non-compliance with the pleading rules

heading.title: Consequences of non-compliance with the pleading rules

p.text: The consequence of failure to comply with the pleading rules depends on the circumstances. As a basic general proposition, the relief available to a party ought be founded on the pleadings: Dare v Pulham (1982) 148 CLR 658 at [6]; 44 ALR 117; 57 ALJR 80; BC8200139 ; Gould v Mount Oxide Mines Ltd (in liq) (1916) 22 CLR 490 at 517; [1916] HCA 81 ; Sri Mahant Govind Rao v Sita Ram Kesho (1898) LR 25 Ind App 195 at 207; Cargill v Bower (1878) 10 Ch D 502 (“further or other relief” is limited to relief consistent with what is expressly asked for). For that reason, the relief sought should be specifically pleaded: Pheeney v Doolan (No 2) [1977] 1 NSWLR 601 . (The general rule is subject to the qualification that the court may grant relief consistent with the matters actually litigated by the parties: Benton v Scott’s Refrigerated Freightways [2008] NSWCA 143; BC200804862 (no consensual abandonment of pleadings by the way the parties conducted themselves): see [s 65.5] and [6.7.5] .
Apart from the formal relief claimed, non compliance with the pleading requirements in relation to material allegations and traverses will shape the litigation. For example:

a failure to plead a material allegation will prevent the fact being litigated, unless an amendment is allowed: Gaunt v Hille (2007) 75 IPR 33; [2007] FCA 2017; BC200711199 ; Ravinder Rohini Pty Ltd v Krizaic (1991) 30 FCR 300 at 314–15; 105 ALR 593 ; Anthony v Esanda Ltd (1980) 32 ALR 627 at 629; 55 ALJR 17; BC8000119 (proceedings conducted on the basis of an unpleaded mutual assumption);
a failure to traverse an allegation will result in the admission of the fact — unless leave to withdraw the admission is granted.
Legislation cited in [14.2.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56.

The present rule complements both the specific pleading requirements in the rules and the obligations imposed on parties by s 56 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 to ensure that only genuine issues are put in dispute in the proceedings. It is another of many provisions encouraging adaptation of the court’s procedures to meet the needs of the particular case and secure the “just, quick and cheap” disposal of proceedings. Its use is particularly appropriate where the litigation does not involve disputed questions of fact: see, for example, Asfar & Co v Blundell [1896] 1 QB 123 ; Union of India v Compania Naviera Aeolus SA [1962] 1 QB 1 ; Jones Construction Co v Alliance Assurance Co [1960] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 264.

level.toc-caption: [14.2.25] Questions of law determinative of injunction proceedings

heading.title: Questions of law determinative of injunction proceedings

p.text: The court may determine questions of law arising on an application for an interlocutory injunction rather than permit them to go for determination at the trial: Administrative & Clerical Officers Assn v Commonwealth (1979) 26 ALR 497; 53 ALJR 588; BC7900093 ; Kolback Securities Ltd v Epoch Mining NL (1987) 8 NSWLR 533 at 535–6; 11 ACLR 630 ; Karaguleski v Vasil Bros & Co Pty Ltd [1981] 1 NSWLR 267; [1981] ANZ ConvR 147Q . See also R Meagher, D Heydon, M Leeming, Meagher, Gummow and Lehane's Equity Doctrines and Remedies, 4th ed, LexisNexis Butterworths, Sydney, 2002 at para [2177]. Indeed, such a course would appear to be desirable where the question is one that is susceptible of resolution on the evidence already available and where there is an adequate opportunity to give proper consideration to the question: Cohen v Peko-Wallsend Ltd (1986) 68 ALR 394 at 397; 61 ALJR 57; BC8601388 ; Segulin v Car Owners Mutual Insurance Co Ltd (1984) NSW Conv R ¶55–191; Kurt Keller Pty Ltd v BMW Australia Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 353 ; see also Spry on Equitable Remedies, 4th ed, Law Book Co, Sydney, 1990, p 457. However, there is no inflexible rule and it is a matter for the discretion of the court in each case whether it is appropriate on an interlocutory application to decide a question of law upon which the resolution of the case depends: Cohen v Peko-Wallsend Ltd, above; cf Francome v Mirror Group Newspapers Ltd [1984] 2 All ER 408; [1984] 1 WLR 892 at 894 ; Victorian Egg Marketing Board v Parkwood Eggs Pty Ltd (1978) 20 ALR 129 at 146; 33 FLR 294 ; American Cyanamid Co v Ethicon Ltd [1975] AC 396 at 407; [1975] 1 All ER 504 ; PRD La Costa Management Pty Ltd v Proprietors — “Beachpoint” Building Units Plan No 3149 [1985] 2 Qd R 227; Hortico (Aust) Pty Ltd v Energy Equipment Co (Aust) Pty Ltd (1985) 1 NSWLR 545 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.3] r 14.3 Defence (cf SCR Part 15, rule 3; DCR Part 10, rule 1; LCR Part 9, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Defence (cf SCR Part 15, rule 3; DCR Part 10, rule 1; LCR Part 9, rule 1)

p.text: Subject to these rules, the time limited for a defendant to file a defence is 28 days after service on the defendant of the statement of claim or such other time as the court directs for the filing of a defence.

If, before the defendant files a defence, a notice of motion for summary judgment under rule 13.1 is served on the defendant, but the court does not on that motion dispose of all of the claims for relief against the defendant, the court may fix a time within which the defendant must file a defence.
See rule 9.11(2) under which a defence to a cross-claim for contribution under section 5 of the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1946 may not be filed unless the court so directs.
The approved forms for a Defence are Form 7A : Defence (where the filing party is legally represented) and Form 7B (where the filing party is acting in person or by authorised officer).
In proceedings in the Supreme Court or the District Court, a plaintiff may file a reply to a defence.
In proceedings in the Local Court, a plaintiff may file a reply to a defence only by leave of the Court.
[subr (2) am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009]
The time limited for the plaintiff to file a reply is 14 days after service of the defence on the plaintiff.
The approved form is Form 8 : Reply.
Legislation cited in [14.4.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 14.27.

There is an implied joinder of issue on a defence: r 14.27 . For that reason, there is no need for a reply unless the plaintiff intends to rely on particular factual allegations in response to matters raised in the defence. But a plaintiff must respond to a cross-claim with a specific defence and cannot simply join issue with factual allegations pleaded in the cross-claim: Benbow v Low (1880) 13 Ch D 553 ; Green v Sevin (1879) 13 Ch D 589 at 595 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.5] r 14.5 Further pleadings (cf SCR Part 15, rule 5)

p.text: Except by leave of the court, a party to proceedings may not file any pleading subsequent to a reply.
The time limited for a party to seek leave to file a pleading subsequent to a reply (the further pleading) is 14 days after service on the party of the pleading to which further pleading responds.
Leave will not be granted unless the further pleading is really required. See Monck v Smythe [1895] 1 Ir R 200; Harry v Davey (1876) 34 LT 842; Norris v Beazley (1877) 2 CPD 80 .
